org.chronos.chronodb.internal.impl.query.parser.token

Class WhereToken

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.chronos.chronodb.internal.impl.query.parser.token.WhereToken
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    QueryToken

    public class WhereToken
extends java.lang.Object
implements QueryToken
    A WhereToken specifies an atomic filter.

    It consists of three parts:

    • Index name: The name of the index to query.
    • Condition: The condition to apply between the value in the index and the comparison value.
    • Comparison value: The value to match against.
    For example, let's assume there is an index called "name". A WhereToken could represent the following: 
        WHERE("name" Condition.EQUALS "Martin")
    Structurally, the token consists of an indexName and a details object. The details object varies by the kind of index that is being queried (e.g. WhereToken.StringWhereDetails for string search, WhereToken.LongWhereDetails for long search...).

    • Constructor Detail

      • WhereToken

        public WhereToken()
        Constructs an empty WhereToken.

        Please note that the resulting instance is not valid until all setter methods have been invoked on it.

      • WhereToken

        public WhereToken(java.lang.String index,
                  StringCondition condition,
                  TextMatchMode matchMode,
                  java.lang.String searchString)
        Constructs a new WhereToken and calls setStringWhereDetails(StringCondition, TextMatchMode, String) on it.
        Parameters:
        index - The name of the index to refer in this "where" token. Must not be null.
        condition - The condition to apply in this "where" token. Must not be null.
        matchMode - The text match mode to use in this "where" token. See enum literal documentation for details. Must not be null.
        searchString - The search string to assign to this "where" token. Must not be null.

      • WhereToken

        public WhereToken(java.lang.String index,
                  NumberCondition condition,
                  long searchValue)
        Constructs a new WhereToken and calls setLongWhereDetails(NumberCondition, long) on it.
        Parameters:
        index - The name of the index to refer in this "where" token. Must not be null.
        condition - The condition to apply in this "where" token. Must not be null.
        searchValue - The search value to store in this "where" token.

      • WhereToken

        public WhereToken(java.lang.String index,
                  NumberCondition condition,
                  double searchValue,
                  double equalityTolerance)
        Constructs a new WhereToken and calls setLongWhereDetails(NumberCondition, long) on it.
        Parameters:
        index - The name of the index to refer in this "where" token. Must not be null.
        condition - The condition to apply in this "where" token. Must not be null.
        searchValue - The search value to store in this "where" token.
        equalityTolerance - The equality tolerance to store in this "where" token. It is the maximum absolute difference between two doubles that are still considered to be "equal". Must not be negative.

    • Method Detail

      • getIndexName

        public java.lang.String getIndexName()
        Returns the name of the index.
        Returns:
        The index name. Never null.

      • setIndexName

        public void setIndexName(java.lang.String indexName)

        Parameters:
        indexName - The name of the index. Must not be null.

      • setStringWhereDetails

        public void setStringWhereDetails(StringCondition condition,
                                  TextMatchMode matchMode,
                                  java.lang.String comparisonValue)
        Sets the WhereToken.StringWhereDetails on this token.

        Please note that any WhereToken can have at most one details object assigned at any point in time. If there already is a details object of a different type attached, this method will throw an IllegalStateException. If there is a details object of the same type attached, its values will be overwritten.

        Parameters:
        condition - The condition to store in this "where" token. Must not be null.
        matchMode - The text match mode to store in this "where" token. Must not be null.
        comparisonValue - The comparison value to store in this "where" token. Must not be null.

      • setLongWhereDetails

        public void setLongWhereDetails(NumberCondition condition,
                                long comparisonValue)
        Sets the WhereToken.LongWhereDetails on this token.

        Please note that any WhereToken can have at most one details object assigned at any point in time. If there already is a details object of a different type attached, this method will throw an IllegalStateException. If there is a details object of the same type attached, its values will be overwritten.

        Parameters:
        condition - The condition to store in this "where" token. Must not be null.
        comparisonValue - The comparison value to store in this "where" token.

      • setDoubleDetails

        public void setDoubleDetails(NumberCondition condition,
                             double comparisonValue,
                             double equalityTolerance)
        Sets the WhereToken.DoubleWhereDetails on this token.

        Please note that any WhereToken can have at most one details object assigned at any point in time. If there already is a details object of a different type attached, this method will throw an IllegalStateException. If there is a details object of the same type attached, its values will be overwritten.

        Parameters:
        condition - The condition to store in this "where" token. Must not be null.
        comparisonValue - The comparison value to store in this "where" token.
        equalityTolerance - The equality tolerance to store in this "where" token. Must not be negative.

      • asStringWhereToken

        public WhereToken.StringWhereDetails asStringWhereToken()
        Returns the WhereToken.StringWhereDetails attached to this element.

        Please note that a WhereToken can have at most one "details" object attached. If there is no details object attached, or a details object of a different type is attached, then this method will throw an IllegalStateException. Use isStringWhereToken() first to check if calling this method is safe or not.

        Returns:
        The details object. Never null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - Thrown if no details object is present or it is of the wrong type.

      • asLongWhereToken

        public WhereToken.LongWhereDetails asLongWhereToken()
        Returns the WhereToken.LongWhereDetails attached to this element.

        Please note that a WhereToken can have at most one "details" object attached. If there is no details object attached, or a details object of a different type is attached, then this method will throw an IllegalStateException. Use isLongWhereToken() first to check if calling this method is safe or not.

        Returns:
        The details object. Never null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - Thrown if no details object is present or it is of the wrong type.

      • asDoubleWhereToken

        public WhereToken.DoubleWhereDetails asDoubleWhereToken()
        Returns the WhereToken.DoubleWhereDetails attached to this element.

        Please note that a WhereToken can have at most one "details" object attached. If there is no details object attached, or a details object of a different type is attached, then this method will throw an IllegalStateException. Use isDoubleWhereToken() first to check if calling this method is safe or not.

        Returns:
        The details object. Never null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - Thrown if no details object is present or it is of the wrong type.

      • isStringWhereToken

        public boolean isStringWhereToken()
        Checks if this element has WhereToken.StringWhereDetails assigned to it.
        Returns:
        true if StringWhereDetails are assigned, otherwise false.

        public boolean hasDetailsAssigned()
